comments.raw_text:
We have issues in Fennec native as we need to control the scroll position of a page, but we also need to respect scroll requests that come from JavaScript.

Currently, we insert our scroll requests in JavaScript and we have some heuristics to determine if ours have been overwritten to send back to the browser to update its display, but they don't work very well.

Ideally, we'd control the scroll position completely and JavaScript in a page trying to change the scroll position of its browser element could be intercepted and allowed/disallowed.

IRC discussion has lead to the suggestion of an nsIScrollMediator interface, and an nsIDOMWindowUtils::SetScrollMediator() function.

Feedback (and volunteering!) would be much appreciated.

nsIScrollMediator already exists. You mean you want to use it?

Can you handle requests synchronously or does this have to be a fully async interface?

What exactly do you need to do in response to Web page scroll requests?

comments.text:
Most simply, we need to be able to stop a web page from scrolling - we can then set the scroll ourselves later, once we've evaluated it with respect to the scroll we want.

I guess this kind of thing may break some JS that expects to be able to set scrollTop/Left and immediately read it back however, so I guess ideally we'd want an asynchronous API to block the scroll event and allow it later on (which I guess would pause execution of JS).
